elements.title: Trust-Signal-First Hierarchy for Host Evaluation Screens
elements.problem: When hosts evaluate a potential guest match, the platform must answer the same predictable questions every traditional landlord asks: income, employment, credit, references. Jason's call reveals that income verification is the very first question he asks (06:14) -- before term, move-in date, or furnishing preferences. Bryant could not answer it precisely (06:21: 'I'd have to look that up'), forcing a deferral. The platform's information hierarchy must lead with the data landlords instinctively seek, not with platform-centric concepts like 'vetting scores' or 'guest profiles.' Jason never asks about a vetting score; he asks 'What's a total income between both of them?' The information architecture must mirror the landlord's mental evaluation tree, where income and employment are the root nodes, not decorative leaves.
elements.solution: Structure every host-facing evaluation screen so that traditional landlord trust signals occupy the primary visual hierarchy position. Income (individual and combined), employment verification status, credit standing, and previous landlord references should be the first data the host's eye encounters. Platform-specific trust signals (deposit matching, rent guarantee) should follow as reinforcing secondary information. Guest personal details (name, preferences, move-in date) occupy the tertiary position. This mirrors how a landlord evaluates an application on paper: financials first, then credentials, then logistics.

evidence.quote: What's a total income between both of them? ... I'd have to look that up. I don't have it handy with me right now.
evidence.insight: Jason's first evaluation question is the most traditional landlord metric: combined income. This reveals his mental hierarchy -- financials are the root of his decision tree. Any screen that buries income below other information forces the host to hunt for the data they instinctively need first.

evidence.quote: They've both been vetted. We verified employment credit and previous landlord references as well. And also we guarantee the rent payment to you as the landlord.
evidence.insight: Bryant front-loads vetting and guarantee information in his verbal pitch, which is effective. The platform's information architecture should replicate this verbal hierarchy: vetting proof first, guarantee second, logistics third.

evidence.quote: It comes down to knowing two things about each idea: (1) How much money or value will this generate? and (2) How much money or time will this cost?
evidence.insight: Cagan's business case framework maps directly to the host's evaluation: the host computes value (guaranteed rent, vetted income) versus cost (process friction, trust risk). The information hierarchy must present value inputs in the order the host's internal business case calculation requires them.

evidence.quote: Behind every great product is someone who led the team to combine technology and design to solve real customer problems in a way that meets the needs of the business.
evidence.insight: The real customer problem is not 'seeing guest information' but 'evaluating a potential tenant against my landlord criteria.' The information architecture must serve the evaluation problem, not merely display data.

elements.hierarchy_principle: Primary: Financial trust signals (individual income, combined income, employment verification, credit status). Secondary: Platform trust signals (rent guarantee, deposit matching, vetting methodology). Tertiary: Logistics and preferences (guest names, move-in date, term preference, furnishing needs). This order mirrors the landlord's decision tree where financial viability gates all subsequent evaluation.
elements.disclosure_pattern: Show all financial trust signals immediately and completely on the evaluation/proposal screen -- no clicks to expand, no 'view details' links. Platform trust signals appear in the same view but visually subordinate. Logistics details can use progressive disclosure (expandable sections) because the host only evaluates them after financials pass muster.
elements.cognitive_load_constraint: Maximum 6 data points visible in the primary hierarchy zone: (1) Guest A income, (2) Guest B income, (3) Combined income, (4) Employment status with employer name, (5) Credit rating or pass/fail, (6) Previous landlord reference status. Each as a single line or number, not a paragraph. The host should be able to scan the financial trust signals in under 5 seconds.
scan_order: Combined guest income (single number, largest font)
Individual income breakdown (two lines, medium font)
Employment and credit verification badges (iconographic, pass/fail)
Rent guarantee and deposit match summary (platform value-add)
Guest names, move-in date, term preference (logistics section)
exclude: Guest personal bios or lifestyle descriptions during initial evaluation -- these distract from the financial decision gate
Platform methodology explanations ('how we vet guests') on the evaluation screen -- move to an FAQ or tooltip
Internal vetting scores or proprietary metrics the host cannot interpret against their own landlord standards
Any request for the host to take action (approve, reject, respond) before they have scanned all financial trust signals

elements.title: Mental Model Bridge Before Process Divergence
elements.problem: Hosts from traditional rental channels carry entrenched expectations about how renting works: in-person showings, direct tenant contact, physical lease signing. When the platform's process diverges from these expectations without explanation, the host perceives the platform as deficient rather than innovative. Jason repeats his concern about no-showings twice (10:50: 'sounds a bit odd'; 12:35: 'a lot of people are like, this just sounds weird to me'), escalating his language each time. The platform's information architecture currently assumes the host will accept process divergences as given. Instead, every divergence point requires a structured information bridge that validates the traditional expectation, names the divergence, and explains the equivalent protection the platform provides.
elements.solution: At every point where the platform's process differs from traditional landlord expectations, present a three-part information bridge: (1) Acknowledge -- name the traditional expectation ('Most landlords do in-person showings before signing'). (2) Explain -- state why the platform works differently ('Our guests review detailed photo tours and verified property data'). (3) Protect -- show what equivalent protection the host gets ('If guests are unsatisfied within 48 hours, our guarantee covers any vacancy gap'). This bridge must appear proactively at the point of divergence, not in response to a complaint. The information should use the host's vocabulary ('showing,' 'income,' 'lease') not platform jargon ('virtual tour,' 'vetting score,' 'stay agreement').

evidence.quote: I've been doing showings. It sounds a bit odd that they don't want to see the place before they move in.
evidence.insight: Jason's first mention of the showing concern uses mild language ('a bit odd'), signaling surprise but not rejection. This is the moment the information bridge should deploy -- before the concern hardens into an objection.

evidence.quote: A lot of people are like, this just sounds weird to me that they want to sign a lease without seeing it.
evidence.insight: By the second mention, Jason has escalated to 'weird' and is generalizing to 'a lot of people,' indicating the concern has solidified into a structural objection. The information architecture failed to bridge the gap at first mention, allowing the concern to compound.

evidence.quote: Technology-powered products do not need to be purely digital. Many of the best examples today are blends of online and offline experiences -- like getting a ride or a room for the night.
evidence.insight: Cagan's principle that the best products blend online and offline directly supports accommodating traditional expectations rather than eliminating them. The platform should offer the bridge to its digital process, not demand the host abandon their offline mental model.

evidence.quote: This model leads to stakeholder-driven products and sales-driven specials... this is not the source of our best product ideas.
evidence.insight: Cagan identifies that stakeholder-driven decisions (like a no-showing policy) miss actual user needs. The no-showing default was likely an operational decision, not a user-validated one. The information architecture must compensate for this product gap by providing explicit bridging content.

elements.hierarchy_principle: Primary: The traditional expectation acknowledgment ('You may expect in-person showings -- most landlords do'). Secondary: The platform's alternative process and why it exists. Tertiary: The equivalent protection or accommodation offered. This hierarchy puts the host's world first, the platform's world second, and the safety net third -- validating before educating.
elements.disclosure_pattern: Deploy the mental model bridge proactively at the exact moment the divergence becomes visible to the host. For showings: when the host first sees the proposal screen that has no 'Schedule Showing' button. For income verification: when the host sees a platform vetting format instead of a traditional application. Each bridge is a compact inline callout (not a modal or popup), visible without interaction, that the host can read in one scan or skip if already familiar.
elements.cognitive_load_constraint: Each mental model bridge must be expressible in 3 sentences or fewer: one for acknowledge, one for explain, one for protect. Maximum 40 words total. The host should absorb the bridge in under 8 seconds without needing to click, scroll, or navigate away. No more than 2 bridges visible on any single screen to avoid overwhelming the host with 'differences.'
scan_order: Acknowledgment of the traditional expectation (bold or highlighted, host's vocabulary)
Brief explanation of the platform's approach (normal weight, factual tone)
Equivalent protection or accommodation offered (actionable link or badge)
exclude: Defensive language ('we do this for your protection' or 'this is actually better') -- let the host judge
Platform jargon as the primary framing ('virtual property assessment' instead of 'online photos and walkthrough')
Multiple divergence explanations stacked on one screen -- space them across the journey to avoid overwhelming
Any implication that the host's traditional expectation is wrong or outdated

elements.title: Progressive Proposal Disclosure Aligned to Decision Sequence
elements.problem: The host's evaluation of a guest proposal follows a specific cognitive sequence: first financial viability (can they pay?), then term compatibility (does the timing work?), then operational fit (furniture, showings, cleaning), then final decision. Jason's call reveals this sequence clearly: income question (06:14), term question (06:43), furniture discussion (07:55-08:19), showing question (10:18). But the current process dumps all information in a single phone call with no structure, forcing the host to mentally sort and sequence. On a platform screen, if the proposal presents all information simultaneously -- financials, logistics, furnishing, and terms in a flat layout -- the host must do cognitive triage to find their decision-sequence starting point. The information architecture must pre-sort the proposal into the host's natural decision sequence.
elements.solution: Structure the proposal view as a progressive sequence that matches the host's decision tree. The first visible section presents the financial case (income, guarantee, deposit). Only after the host has scanned this section should the term and timing details become prominent. Operational details (furniture preferences, showing requests, cleaning expectations) appear in a final section that the host reaches only after the financial and term questions are resolved. Each section can include a micro-decision point ('Financials look good? Continue to review terms') that both confirms the host's progress and prevents information overload from seeing everything at once.

evidence.quote: What's a total income between both of them? [06:14] ... you were saying something about the term [06:43] ... they're looking for a furnished place [07:55] ... do people want to see the place? [10:18]
evidence.insight: Jason's questions follow a strict sequence: money, time, stuff, trust. This is not random -- it is the traditional landlord's decision tree. The proposal must be structured to mirror this sequence, not fight it.

evidence.quote: They're considering other places as well, right? Yes. Yep. They're taking a look at a couple other places.
evidence.insight: Both sides have alternatives. A well-structured proposal that accelerates the host's decision sequence reduces the time spent in evaluation limbo, where competing alternatives can capture the host or the guest.

evidence.quote: There is always a ton of things from different parts of the business that need to be done. Companies want to prioritize these ideas into a roadmap.
evidence.insight: Just as product roadmaps must prioritize ideas by impact, proposal screens must prioritize information by the host's decision sequence. Presenting everything simultaneously is the information equivalent of an unprioritized backlog.

evidence.quote: The reality of life in the startup is that you are in a race to achieve product/market fit before you run out of money. Nothing else matters until you invent a strong product that meets initial market needs.
evidence.insight: Each host interaction has a conversion runway. A proposal that respects the host's decision sequence accelerates evaluation, compressing the time to commitment and reducing the risk that competing alternatives capture either party.

elements.hierarchy_principle: Primary: Financial viability (income, rent guarantee, deposit details) -- this gates all subsequent evaluation. Secondary: Term and timing (lease duration, start date, flexibility) -- only relevant once financials pass. Tertiary: Operational fit (furniture preferences, showing option, cleaning coordination) -- only relevant once term is acceptable. This mirrors the landlord's actual decision tree as evidenced by Jason's question sequence.
elements.disclosure_pattern: Use a stepped or sectioned layout where the financial section is fully visible on load. Term details are visible but visually subordinate (smaller type, below the fold, or in a collapsed-but-labeled section). Operational details are in a clearly labeled section that the host navigates to after reviewing financials and terms. Each section transition includes a brief contextual connector ('Financials reviewed. Here are the proposed terms.'). The host can jump to any section but the default flow follows the decision sequence.
elements.cognitive_load_constraint: Maximum 3 decision sections per proposal view. Each section contains no more than 4 data points. The host should be able to complete a full proposal review in under 3 minutes. No single section should require scrolling on a standard laptop screen. The total proposal view should fit within 2 scroll-lengths maximum.
scan_order: Financial summary block (combined income, rent amount, guarantee badge, deposit structure)
Term block (proposed duration, start date, flexibility indicator)
Operational block (furniture preferences, showing availability, special requests)
Action zone (express interest, request changes, decline)
exclude: Guest bios or personal stories in the financial section -- these create emotional noise during a financial evaluation
Platform fee structure or business model explanations within the proposal -- host should already know this from onboarding
Detailed vetting methodology ('how we verified income') in the main proposal flow -- move to an expandable tooltip
Any information that requires the host to compare against external data they do not have on hand (e.g., market rate comparisons, neighborhood averages)

elements.title: Operational Knowledge Capture Through Guided Conversational Prompts
elements.problem: Hosts possess rich, experience-based operational knowledge about their properties that is critical to guest satisfaction but has no structured home in a standard listing form. Jason spent nearly a quarter of his 14-minute call (03:15-05:14) on a parking tutorial covering street cleaning schedules, time-of-day patterns, garage pricing, and historical behavior. He also described furniture conditions with honest caveats (08:19: 'not the highest quality'), building security constraints on furniture movement (08:55-09:27), and conditional cleaning plans (11:17). This knowledge exists only in the host's memory and in conversation. If the listing form offers only standard fields (price, bedrooms, amenities), this operational intelligence is lost. Guests arrive without it, leading to complaints, friction, and host dissatisfaction. The information architecture must create structured pathways to capture what the host already knows.
elements.solution: Replace generic listing form labels with guided conversational prompts that elicit the host's operational knowledge. Instead of 'Transportation Notes,' ask 'What should guests know about parking near your place?' Instead of 'Property Condition,' ask 'Anything guests should know about the furniture or space before they arrive?' Each prompt should accept a short free-text answer (1-3 sentences) and offer optional structured sub-fields (street cleaning day, nearest garage, price range). The prompts are organized by the guest's arrival sequence: (1) Getting there (parking, transit, building access), (2) Settling in (furniture condition, amenities, building rules), (3) Living there (neighborhood tips, maintenance contacts, recurring schedules). The captured knowledge surfaces as a dynamic house manual during the active lease.

evidence.quote: Parking battery park city, the parking is quite tough because it's the business district... street cleaning once a week... sometimes it'll take an hour if it's maybe Saturday night... there are also some parking spots that open up after the work day.
evidence.insight: Jason spends 3 minutes on parking alone -- detailed, time-sensitive, location-specific knowledge that no standard form captures. This is exactly the kind of operational intelligence that prevents guest friction if captured and surfaced properly.

evidence.quote: It can be flipped on, but it's not the highest quality... people come in and they're like, oh, there's like a dirt stain... but they could also get another bed or another type of thing to put on top of it.
evidence.insight: Jason is transparent about furniture quality and preemptively suggests solutions. The listing architecture must support this kind of honest, nuanced condition reporting -- not suppress it into a binary 'furnished: yes/no' field.

evidence.quote: Technology-powered products do not need to be purely digital. Many of the best examples today are blends of online and offline experiences -- like getting a ride or a room for the night.
evidence.insight: Cagan explicitly references room-rental marketplaces as online-offline blends. The offline component (parking, building rules, furniture conditions) is substantial. The information architecture must bridge this offline knowledge into the online platform.

evidence.quote: Behind every great product is someone who led the team to combine technology and design to solve real customer problems in a way that meets the needs of the business.
evidence.insight: The real customer problem is the gap between what the host knows about their property and what guests need to know. Capturing operational knowledge solves both the guest's information need and the host's desire to avoid repetitive complaints.

elements.hierarchy_principle: Primary: Arrival-critical information (parking, building access, key pickup) -- guests need this before they arrive. Secondary: Living-context information (furniture conditions, amenity details, building rules) -- guests need this when settling in. Tertiary: Neighborhood knowledge (local tips, recurring schedules, nearby services) -- guests discover this over time. This hierarchy follows the guest's temporal experience sequence.
elements.disclosure_pattern: During listing creation, present operational knowledge prompts after the host has completed the required fields (price, availability, photos). The prompts appear as a 'Help your guests arrive prepared' section with 3-5 conversational questions. Each prompt is optional but labeled with a completion indicator ('3 of 5 tips added'). During the active lease, surface the captured knowledge as a formatted house manual that guests see pre-arrival. The host can update any field at any time with a single edit.
elements.cognitive_load_constraint: Maximum 5 operational knowledge prompts during listing creation. Each prompt accepts 1-3 sentences of free text. The entire section should take under 5 minutes to complete. During guest-facing display, each operational knowledge item is a single card or tile: icon, title (e.g., 'Parking'), 2-3 sentences of host-written content. Maximum 8 cards in the house manual view.
scan_order: Arrival essentials (parking, building access, key/code)
Space details (furniture inventory, condition notes, available amenities)
Building rules (pets, noise, security, guest policies)
Neighborhood context (transit, grocery, recurring schedules)
exclude: Open-ended text boxes with no guidance ('Additional notes about your property') -- these produce either nothing or unfocused content
Listing-level descriptions that duplicate what photos already show (room dimensions, wall colors)
Information that changes frequently enough to become stale within a month (specific construction schedules, temporary parking restrictions) unless the platform provides easy update mechanisms
Legal or liability disclaimers mixed into the operational knowledge section -- keep legal in its own space

elements.title: Configurable Attribute Disclosure for Negotiable Property State
elements.problem: Traditional listing platforms force binary property attributes: furnished or unfurnished, pet-friendly or not. Jason's call reveals that real property attributes are conditional and negotiable. He has a bed (good), a futon (functional but 'not the highest quality,' 08:19), 4 tables/desks ('really need all of that' is questionable, 11:52), and cleaning plans that depend on the tenant's preferences (11:17-11:38). When a listing says 'furnished,' Jason means 'I can leave some furniture, the bed is good, the futon is mediocre, and I am willing to adjust based on what the tenant needs.' A binary checkbox loses this nuance, creating expectation mismatches that surface during proposal negotiation or after move-in. The information architecture must express property state as a configurable spectrum, not a fixed snapshot.
elements.solution: Replace binary attribute fields with a three-state model for negotiable items: Included (will be there), Available (can be there, with condition note), and Removable (can be taken out on request). Each item in the furnished inventory gets its own line with a state selector and an optional condition note field. During proposal management, present these configurable attributes as explicit negotiation points: the guest sees the host's default configuration and can request changes. The host confirms or adjusts. This transforms the listing from a static advertisement into a collaborative configuration tool.

evidence.quote: There's actually too many tables. So I can just move out a couple of the tables. There's four tables and desks. Really need all of that.
evidence.insight: Jason is actively willing to customize the space. A binary 'furnished: yes' field cannot express this flexibility. The information architecture must support item-level configurability.

evidence.quote: It can be flipped on, but it's not the highest quality. I can let them know.
evidence.insight: Jason is transparent about quality. A listing that only allows 'futon: yes/no' forces the host to either omit the caveat (guest disappointment) or explain it outside the platform (process fragmentation). The architecture must support inline condition notes.

evidence.quote: I'm going to do a deep cleaning after I... well, I haven't decided what I've moved the furniture out because it depends on the tenant.
evidence.insight: Jason's cleaning and furniture decisions are interdependent and tenant-dependent. The listing cannot be finalized in isolation -- it must support iterative refinement during proposal negotiation.

evidence.quote: There is always a ton of things from different parts of the business that need to be done. Companies want to prioritize these ideas into a roadmap.
evidence.insight: Just as product roadmaps should be responsive to discovery, listing schemas should be responsive to the host's actual property state. A rigid schema that forces premature finalization is the listing equivalent of a waterfall process.

elements.hierarchy_principle: Primary: Item name and state (Included / Available / Removable) -- the host and guest need to see what is definite vs. negotiable at a glance. Secondary: Condition notes -- honest caveats attached to 'Available' items (e.g., 'functional but not premium quality'). Tertiary: Configuration change history -- what was adjusted during proposal negotiation. This hierarchy puts the current state first, quality context second, and negotiation history third.
elements.disclosure_pattern: During listing creation, present the furniture inventory as a checklist with three-state toggles per item. Condition notes appear as optional inline fields that expand when 'Available' is selected. During proposal management, the guest sees the host's default configuration with clearly marked negotiable items. The guest can request changes, which appear as inline annotations the host reviews. After agreement, the listing state updates to the confirmed configuration.
elements.cognitive_load_constraint: Maximum 10 items in the furniture/amenity inventory. Each item occupies one line: name, state toggle, optional condition note (max 20 words). The entire inventory should be scannable in under 30 seconds. During proposal negotiation, only items with requested changes are highlighted -- unchanged items fade to reduce visual noise.
scan_order: Inventory overview (how many items total, how many negotiable)
Included items (definite, no action needed)
Available items with condition notes (review quality caveats)
Removable items (can be taken out if guest prefers)
Guest change requests (if in proposal negotiation mode)
exclude: Detailed item descriptions beyond condition notes (brand names, purchase dates, original prices) -- these add noise without aiding the host-guest negotiation
Photos of individual furniture items during initial listing creation -- allow but do not require
Cleaning schedule details in the furniture inventory -- keep cleaning in its own operational section
Any suggestion that available items are included by default -- the 'Available' state must clearly communicate that it requires guest interest to activate

elements.title: Synchronous Activation Link During Call with Pre-Populated Proposal View
elements.problem: The phone call builds engagement momentum -- Jason engaged for 14 minutes, asked detailed questions, and ended cooperatively. But the next touchpoint is an email arriving 'shortly' (13:59) with no specific timeline. Between the call and the email, the host's attention returns to competing priorities: 6 showings, kitchen repairs, deep cleaning. The information architecture currently treats the call and the platform as separate, sequential channels. The host builds a mental model during the call (verbal information about guests, terms, deposit) and then must reconstruct it later from an email or platform screen. This reconstruction is lossy -- details are forgotten, enthusiasm fades, competing alternatives progress. The information architecture must bridge the call and the platform into a single continuous information flow.
elements.solution: During the final 2 minutes of the call, send the host a text message with a direct link to a pre-populated proposal view. The link opens a screen that presents everything discussed in the call, structured according to the host's decision sequence (communicates-003): financial trust signals first, term details second, operational details third. The host can scan this screen while still on the phone with the agent, who confirms: 'Did you get it? You should see Ariel and Amber's proposal for your place.' The screen requires no account creation, no login, no registration -- just the proposal data and a single action button ('Interested -- Tell Me More' or 'Request a Showing'). The information architecture of this first-touch screen must be maximally scannable because the host is dividing attention between the screen and the phone call.

evidence.quote: Could I get your email, send over some information to you after this call? ... I'll follow up with an email shortly.
evidence.insight: The entire onboarding hinges on a future email with no specific timeline. There is no instant activation, no link shared during the call. The transition from verbal information to digital information is fully asynchronous, creating an engagement gap where competing alternatives progress.

evidence.quote: I had done six total showings, but four of them were like a month ago... recently I only did about two showings.
evidence.insight: Jason has active traditional alternatives. During the post-call gap, these alternatives continue progressing. The information architecture must eliminate this gap by making the platform's information available during the call itself.

evidence.quote: Good startups are optimized for learning and moving quickly and normally have very little bureaucracy to slow them down. Still, the very high failure rate of technology startups is no secret.
evidence.insight: Cagan identifies speed as a core startup advantage. Sending the proposal link during the call -- not after -- is the kind of speed optimization that compresses the conversion funnel and reduces competitive attrition.

evidence.quote: Many of the best examples today are blends of online and offline experiences -- like getting a ride or a room for the night.
evidence.insight: The phone call (offline) must seamlessly blend into the platform (online) during the same interaction. The best ride-hailing apps do not ask you to call back later to confirm your ride. The same principle applies: bridge to digital while the offline interaction is still live.

elements.hierarchy_principle: Primary: Property address and guest names (instant confirmation this is the right proposal for the right conversation). Secondary: Financial summary (the trust signals discussed in the call, now visible and verifiable). Tertiary: Single action button (one clear next step, no decision fatigue). This hierarchy is optimized for divided attention -- the host is scanning a screen while on a phone call, so density must be low and recognition must be instant.
elements.disclosure_pattern: The first-touch screen shows only the proposal summary: property address, guest names, combined income, rent amount, term, and one action button. All of this fits above the fold on a mobile screen. Tapping the action button expands to the full proposal view (communicates-003 structure). The host can explore deeper after the call ends, but the first scan happens during the call with minimal cognitive load. No modals, no popups, no interstitials between the link and the proposal summary.
elements.cognitive_load_constraint: The first-touch screen must be fully scannable in under 10 seconds on a mobile phone while the host is simultaneously listening to the agent. Maximum 5 data points visible: (1) property address, (2) guest names, (3) combined income, (4) proposed rent and term, (5) action button. No scrolling required. No text blocks longer than one line. No images that compete for attention with the data.
scan_order: Property address (instant recognition: 'this is about MY place')
Guest names (connection to the conversation: 'these are the people Bryant mentioned')
Financial summary line (income + rent + guarantee in one scannable row)
Action button ('Interested' or 'Request Showing')
Nothing else on the first screen -- deeper details available on tap
exclude: Account creation, login, or registration on the first-touch screen -- value before commitment
Platform branding or marketing copy that consumes screen real estate without serving the host's immediate need
Full guest profiles, detailed vetting reports, or any content that requires focused reading -- save for the post-call deep dive
Terms and conditions, privacy notices, or legal text on the first-touch screen -- these belong in a subsequent step after the host has expressed interest

elements.title: Competitive Context Transparency for Time-Sensitive Decisions
elements.problem: Both sides of the match have active alternatives. Jason has 6 showings and Craigslist. The guests are 'taking a look at a couple other places' (13:26). This creates a dual-sided ticking clock that neither party can see. Jason does not know how many other properties the guests are evaluating or when they will decide. The guests do not know that Jason has active traditional leads. The platform possesses this competitive context but does not surface it, leaving both parties in an information vacuum that encourages procrastination. Without visible time pressure, the host defers decision-making to 'after I get the email,' then to 'after I do the deep cleaning,' then to never. The information architecture must make the decision timeline visible without creating artificial pressure.
elements.solution: Surface transparent, factual competitive context at key decision points. On the proposal screen, show the host: 'Ariel and Amber are reviewing [X] properties and plan to decide by [date].' This is not artificial urgency -- it is factual context the host needs to calibrate their decision timing. Similarly, inform the host of their own timeline: 'You received this proposal on [date]. Average host response time is [X] days.' The competitive context should be presented as neutral information, not as pressure copy. It respects the host's agency while making the cost of delay visible.

evidence.quote: They're considering other places as well, right? Yes. Yep. They're taking a look at a couple other places.
evidence.insight: Jason proactively asks about competitive context -- he wants to know where he stands relative to other options. The platform should answer this question before the host needs to ask it.

evidence.quote: I'll follow up with an email shortly. And like I said, if you have questions for me, text email either way, anytime works.
evidence.insight: The call ends with zero urgency signal. 'Shortly' and 'anytime' create an open-ended timeline that encourages delay. The information architecture must replace vague timing with specific, visible decision windows.

evidence.quote: The reality of life in the startup is that you are in a race to achieve product/market fit before you run out of money.
evidence.insight: Cagan's funding-runway metaphor translates directly to each host interaction: Split Lease has a conversion runway with each host that burns down as alternatives progress. Making this runway visible to the host (as a decision timeline) aligns the host's actions with the platform's conversion needs.

evidence.quote: Strong technology product companies know they must ensure consistent product innovation. This means constantly creating new value for their customers and for their business.
evidence.insight: Every moment of delay without new value creation allows competitive alternatives to create value instead. Transparent timelines are themselves a form of value -- they help the host make better-timed decisions rather than defaulting to inaction.

elements.hierarchy_principle: Primary: Guest decision timeline ('Guests plan to decide by [date]') -- this is the most actionable piece of competitive context. Secondary: Proposal status indicator ('Proposal sent [X] days ago, awaiting your response') -- this makes the host's own delay visible. Tertiary: General market context ('Properties in [area] typically fill within [X] days') -- background calibration, not pressure. The hierarchy puts the most time-sensitive and actionable information first.
elements.disclosure_pattern: Show the guest decision timeline on the proposal screen as a subtle but visible status bar or badge. Do not use countdown timers or red warning colors -- use neutral, informational design (a date, a status label). The proposal age indicator appears after the proposal has been open for 24+ hours without action, presented as a gentle nudge ('Sent 2 days ago'). Market context is available on hover or in a details section, not prominent by default.
elements.cognitive_load_constraint: Maximum 2 competitive context data points visible on the proposal screen at any time: the guest's decision timeline and the proposal age. Market context is hidden behind a tap or hover. No competitive context information should require more than 3 seconds to scan. Avoid percentage-based metrics ('75% of hosts respond within 48 hours') that trigger social comparison anxiety.
scan_order: Guest decision timeline date or window (factual, specific)
Proposal status / age indicator (neutral, informational)
Action button (what to do now)
Market context (available on request, not prominent)
exclude: Countdown timers or urgency-inducing visual patterns (red text, flashing elements, 'running out' language)
Social proof pressure ('12 other hosts responded in under 24 hours') -- this creates anxiety, not informed decision-making
Threat-framed messaging ('You may lose this match if you don't respond') -- use opportunity framing instead
Competitive context about the host's own alternatives ('You have 6 showings scheduled') -- the platform should not presume to know the host's full situation
